natural problem: What is the measure of the smaller angle between the hands of a 12-hour clock at 12:25 pm, in degrees? Express your answer as a decimal to the nearest tenth.
natural solution: Every minute, the minute hand moves $360 \div 60 = 6$ degrees. At 25 minutes past the hour, the minute hand is $25 \times 6 = 150$ degrees past the vertical 12:00 position. Every minute, the hour hand moves $360 \div 12 \div 60 = 0.5$ degrees.

At 25 minutes past 12:00, the hour hand is $25 \times 0.5 = 12.5$ degrees past the vertical 12:00 position. The angle between the hands of the clock at 12:25 is $150 - 12.5 = \boxed{137.5\text{ degrees}}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes time :: real
assumes h0 : "time = 12.25"
shows  "let minute_angle = 360 * (time mod 1);
           hour_angle = 360 * (time div 1) / 12;
           angle_diff = abs(minute_angle - hour_angle)
       in if angle_diff > 180 then 360 - angle_diff else angle_diff = 137.5"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the measure of the smaller angle between the hands of a 12-hour clock at 12:25 pm, in degrees? Express your answer as a decimal to the nearest tenth. The final Answer is 137.5\text{ degrees}
 ### Proof
 Every minute, the minute hand moves $360 \div 60 = 6$ degrees. At 25 minutes past the hour, the minute hand is $25 \times 6 = 150$ degrees past the vertical 12:00 position. Every minute, the hour hand moves $360 \div 12 \div 60 = 0.5$ degrees.
 At 25 minutes past 12:00, the hour hand is $25 \times 0.5 = 12.5$ degrees past the vertical 12:00 position. The angle between the hands of the clock at 12:25 is $150 - 12.5 = \boxed{137.5\text{ degrees}}$.
 [asy] unitsize(2.5 cm); int i; draw(Circle((0,0),1)); for (i = 0; i <= 11; ++i) {   draw(0.9*dir(30*i)--dir(30*i));   label("$" + string(i + 1) + "$", 1.15*dir(90 - 30*i - 30)); } draw((0,0)--0.8*dir(300));
 draw((0,0)--0.6*dir(90 - 12/25*30)); [/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes time :: real
assumes h0 : "time = 12.25"
shows  "let minute_angle = 360 * (time mod 1);
           hour_angle = 360 * (time div 1) / 12;
           angle_diff = abs(minute_angle - hour_angle)
       in if angle_diff > 180 then 360 - angle_diff else angle_diff = 137.5"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Calculate the angle between the hour and the minute hand on a clock at 12.25 o'clock. If the angle difference is greater than 180 degrees, subtract it from 360 degrees. The final angle difference is 137.5 degrees.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes hour minute :: real
assumes h0 : "hour = 12"
and h1 : "minute = 25"
shows  "abs ((30 * hour - 11/2 * minute) mod 360) = 137.5"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the measure of the smaller angle between the hands of a 12-hour clock at 12:25 pm, in degrees? Express your answer as a decimal to the nearest tenth. The final Answer is 137.5\text{ degrees}
 ### Proof
 Every minute, the minute hand moves $360 \div 60 = 6$ degrees. At 25 minutes past the hour, the minute hand is $25 \times 6 = 150$ degrees past the vertical 12:00 position. Every minute, the hour hand moves $360 \div 12 \div 60 = 0.5$ degrees.
 At 25 minutes past 12:00, the hour hand is $25 \times 0.5 = 12.5$ degrees past the vertical 12:00 position. The angle between the hands of the clock at 12:25 is $150 - 12.5 = \boxed{137.5\text{ degrees}}$.
 [asy] unitsize(2.5 cm); int i; draw(Circle((0,0),1)); for (i = 0; i <= 11; ++i) {   draw(0.9*dir(30*i)--dir(30*i));   label("$" + string(i + 1) + "$", 1.15*dir(90 - 30*i - 30)); } draw((0,0)--0.8*dir(300));
 draw((0,0)--0.6*dir(90 - 12/25*30)); [/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes hour minute :: real
assumes h0 : "hour = 12"
and h1 : "minute = 25"
shows  "abs ((30 * hour - 11/2 * minute) mod 360) = 137.5"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Calculate the absolute value of the angle between the hour and minute hands of a clock at 12:25. The final answer is 137.5 degrees.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes hour :: real
assumes h0 : "hour = 12.0 + (25/60)"
shows  "abs ((360/12) * (hour mod 12) - (360/60) * (hour mod 1)) = 137.5"
a_2.formal solution:

 [asy] unitsize(2.5 cm); int i; draw(Circle((0,0),1)); for (i = 0; i <= 11; ++i) {   draw(0.9*dir(30*i)--dir(30*i));   label("$" + string(i + 1) + "$", 1.15*dir(90 - 30*i - 30)); } draw((0,0)--0.8*dir(300));
 draw((0,0)--0.6*dir(90 - 12/25*30)); [/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes hour :: real
assumes h0 : "hour = 12.0 + (25/60)"
shows  "abs ((360/12) * (hour mod 12) - (360/60) * (hour mod 1)) = 137.5"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Find the absolute difference between the positions of the hour and minute hands on a clock at 12:25. The final answer is 137.5 degrees.

a_3.formal problem:

fixes smaller_angle :: real
assumes h0 : "smaller_angle = abs ((12 * 30) - (25 * 11))"
shows  "smaller_angle = 137.5"

fixes smaller_angle :: real
assumes h0 : "smaller_angle = abs ((12 * 30) - (25 * 11))"

a_3.informal problem: Calculate the smaller angle between the hour and minute hand of a clock at 12:25. The final answer is $137.5$ degrees.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes degrees :: real
assumes h0 : "1 * degrees = 360 / 12 * hours"
and h1 : "1 * degrees = 360 / 60 * minutes"
shows  "((12 - 25/60) * degrees) mod 360 = 137.5"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 ### Proof
 Every minute, the minute hand moves $360 \div 60 = 6$ degrees. At 25 minutes past the hour, the minute hand is $25 \times 6 = 150$ degrees past the vertical 12:00 position. Every minute, the hour hand moves $360 \div 12 \div 60 = 0.5$ degrees.

 draw((0,0)--0.6*dir(90 - 12/25*30)); [/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes degrees :: real
assumes h0 : "1 * degrees = 360 / 12 * hours"
and h1 : "1 * degrees = 360 / 60 * minutes"
shows  "((12 - 25/60) * degrees) mod 360 = 137.5"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: If we consider a clock where 1 degree is equal to 30 hours and 1 degree is equal to 6 minutes, find the angle between the hour and minute hand at 12 hours and 25 minutes. The final answer is 137.5 degrees.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes h m :: real
assumes h0 : "h = 12"
and h1 : "m = 25"
and h2 : "h \<ge> 1"
and h3 : "h \<le> 12"
and h4 : "m \<ge> 0"
and h5 : "m < 60"
shows  "abs (30 * h - 11 * m / 2) = 137.5"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the measure of the smaller angle between the hands of a 12-hour clock at 12:25 pm, in degrees? Express your answer as a decimal to the nearest tenth. The final Answer is 137.5\text{ degrees}

 Every minute, the minute hand moves $360 \div 60 = 6$ degrees. At 25 minutes past the hour, the minute hand is $25 \times 6 = 150$ degrees past the vertical 12:00 position. Every minute, the hour hand moves $360 \div 12 \div 60 = 0.5$ degrees.
 At 25 minutes past 12:00, the hour hand is $25 \times 0.5 = 12.5$ degrees past the vertical 12:00 position. The angle between the hands of the clock at 12:25 is $150 - 12.5 = \boxed{137.5\text{ degrees}}$.

 draw((0,0)--0.6*dir(90 - 12/25*30)); [/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes h m :: real
assumes h0 : "h = 12"
and h1 : "m = 25"
and h2 : "h \<ge> 1"
and h3 : "h \<le> 12"
and h4 : "m \<ge> 0"
and h5 : "m < 60"
shows  "abs (30 * h - 11 * m / 2) = 137.5"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: What is the absolute value of the difference between the hour and minute hand on a clock at 12:25? The final answer is 137.5 degrees.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes hours minutes :: real
assumes h0 : "hours = 12"
and h1 : "minutes = 25"
shows  "abs(0.5 * (60 * hours - 11 * minutes)) = 137.5"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the measure of the smaller angle between the hands of a 12-hour clock at 12:25 pm, in degrees? Express your answer as a decimal to the nearest tenth. The final Answer is 137.5\text{ degrees}

 Every minute, the minute hand moves $360 \div 60 = 6$ degrees. At 25 minutes past the hour, the minute hand is $25 \times 6 = 150$ degrees past the vertical 12:00 position. Every minute, the hour hand moves $360 \div 12 \div 60 = 0.5$ degrees.

 draw((0,0)--0.6*dir(90 - 12/25*30)); [/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes hours minutes :: real
assumes h0 : "hours = 12"
and h1 : "minutes = 25"
shows  "abs(0.5 * (60 * hours - 11 * minutes)) = 137.5"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Calculate the absolute value of the angle (in degrees) between the hour and minute hands of a clock when the time is 12:25. The final answer is 137.5 degrees.

theorem
fixes hour minute :: real
assumes h0 : "hour = 12"
and h1 : "minute = 25"
shows  "abs (30 * hour - 11 / 2 * minute) = 137.5"

fixes hour minute :: real
assumes h0 : "hour = 12"
and h1 : "minute = 25"
shows  "abs (30 * hour - 11 / 2 * minute) = 137.5"

  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Calculate the absolute value of the difference between 30 times the hour (with the hour being 12) and 11/2 times the minute (with the minute being 25). The final answer is 137.5.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes m :: real
assumes h0 : "m = abs ((30 * (12 mod 12) - 11 * 25) mod 360)"
shows  "m = 137.5"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the measure of the smaller angle between the hands of a 12-hour clock at 12:25 pm, in degrees? Express your answer as a decimal to the nearest tenth. The final Answer is 137.5\text{ degrees}
 ### Proof
 Every minute, the minute hand moves $360 \div 60 = 6$ degrees. At 25 minutes past the hour, the minute hand is $25 \times 6 = 150$ degrees past the vertical 12:00 position. Every minute, the hour hand moves $360 \div 12 \div 60 = 0.5$ degrees.
 At 25 minutes past 12:00, the hour hand is $25 \times 0.5 = 12.5$ degrees past the vertical 12:00 position. The angle between the hands of the clock at 12:25 is $150 - 12.5 = \boxed{137.5\text{ degrees}}$.
 [asy] unitsize(2.5 cm); int i; draw(Circle((0,0),1)); for (i = 0; i <= 11; ++i) {   draw(0.9*dir(30*i)--dir(30*i));   label("$" + string(i + 1) + "$", 1.15*dir(90 - 30*i - 30)); } draw((0,0)--0.8*dir(300));
 draw((0,0)--0.6*dir(90 - 12/25*30)); [/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes m :: real
assumes h0 : "m = abs ((30 * (12 mod 12) - 11 * 25) mod 360)"
shows  "m = 137.5"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Calculate the absolute value of the remainder when $(30 * (12 mod 12) - 11 * 25)$ is divided by $360$. The final answer is $137.5$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes time :: real
assumes h0 : "time = 12.25"
shows  "137.5 = (360/12) * abs(time - (30 * (time mod 1)) mod 360)"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the measure of the smaller angle between the hands of a 12-hour clock at 12:25 pm, in degrees? Express your answer as a decimal to the nearest tenth. The final Answer is 137.5\text{ degrees}
 ### Proof
 Every minute, the minute hand moves $360 \div 60 = 6$ degrees. At 25 minutes past the hour, the minute hand is $25 \times 6 = 150$ degrees past the vertical 12:00 position. Every minute, the hour hand moves $360 \div 12 \div 60 = 0.5$ degrees.
 At 25 minutes past 12:00, the hour hand is $25 \times 0.5 = 12.5$ degrees past the vertical 12:00 position. The angle between the hands of the clock at 12:25 is $150 - 12.5 = \boxed{137.5\text{ degrees}}$.
 [asy] unitsize(2.5 cm); int i; draw(Circle((0,0),1)); for (i = 0; i <= 11; ++i) {   draw(0.9*dir(30*i)--dir(30*i));   label("$" + string(i + 1) + "$", 1.15*dir(90 - 30*i - 30)); } draw((0,0)--0.8*dir(300));
 draw((0,0)--0.6*dir(90 - 12/25*30)); [/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes time :: real
assumes h0 : "time = 12.25"
shows  "137.5 = (360/12) * abs(time - (30 * (time mod 1)) mod 360)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Calculate the angle between the hour and minute hands of a clock at 12.25 time. The final answer is 137.5 degrees.
